questions.question_text:
Note: This question is a part of a series of questions that presents the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
SharePoint administrators open several Microsoft support tickets.
You need to view the status of the support tickets.
Solution: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, you select Health, and then you select Message center.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: Solution: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, you select Support, and then you select View service requests.
So here the requirement is to find the way to access the current support tickets and they will be under M365 support section
What is the requirement for this question

choices.A: Use the Recycle Bin of Site1.
choices.D: Use the Recycle Bin of the root site collection.
choices.C: Use the Recycle Bin of Marketing.

discussion.content:
A is correct, because the item will stay in the site bin as it is not mentioned someone deleted the recycle bin of the site 1:
In SharePoint Online, items are retained for 93 days from the time you delete them from their original location. They stay in the site Recycle Bin the entire time, unless someone deletes them from there or empties that Recycle Bin. 
https://support.office.com/en-us/article/restore-deleted-items-from-the-site-collection-recycle-bin-5fa924ee-16d7-487b-9a0a-021b9062d14b
The answer should be C, as the recycle bin reside in site collection and not in the subsite

comments.content: Correct, when you browse through subsite recycle bin it show recycle bin of site collection.

discussion.content: Closest is Option A. Dakar you are right that Global Admin may not have the site collection admin (SCA) rights for that site, However, with Global Admin rights, you can technically grant yourself the SCA right and then you have access to perform restoration.

Technically none of these answers are correct because the scenario states you are a global admin. Global Admin\SP Admin roles are not given Site Collection Administration access to SPO sites by default, thus you would not be able to perform any of the steps within the site until that access is granted explicitly.

Assuming you gave yourself access though, if an item is deleted from a subsite, the file will show up in the site collection administration recycling bin as well, so in that case both A and C are correct.

questions.question_text:
You are the global administrator of a Microsoft 365 subscription.
A user named User1 deleted a file 83 days ago from a site named Site1. Site1 is in a site collection named Marketing.
You need to recover the deleted file.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
ExAmMs, You mentioned Set-SPOHubSite, that is basically only setting the PROPERTY for the hubsite itself, not associating anything here which is not the correct answer.

With your point, Add-SPOHubSiteAssociation is more appropriate but from the sequence perspective, You need to run Register-SPOHubSite first
Don’t you have to enable Hub site feature on a site first with the use of Register-SPOHubSite to be able to change its properties with Set-SPOHubSite?

The question asks about what should be run on the new sites that will have a common design. To achieve this Answer C Register-SPOHubSite is not correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/sharepoint-online/register-spohubsite?view=sharepoint-ps

The correct answer is D: Set-SPOHubSite
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/sharepoint-online/set-spohubsite?view=sharepoint-ps

In the associated hub site the top navigation can be configured and will then be shown on the associated sites:
https://support.office.com/en-us/article/customize-the-navigation-on-your-sharepoint-site-3cd61ae7-a9ed-4e1e-bf6d-4655f0bf25ca#hubnav

questions.question_text:
Your company plans to deploy Microsoft SharePoint Online.
You create 15 modern team sites based on the organizational structure of the company.
You need to ensure that the site collections share common navigation and branding.
Which PowerShell cmdlet should you run?

discussion.content:
C is correct
Cause Managed (Metadata) navigation, represents navigation items using a Managed Metadata term set. And here we are asked to use the taxonomy. And also structural navigation is the recommended navigation option in SharePoint Online for classic Sharepoint sites.

C is correct
Cause many sites do not require security trimming, as the navigation structure is often consistent for all users of the site. If security trimming is disabled and a link is added to navigation that not all users have access to, the link will still show but will lead to an access denied message. There is no risk of inadvertent access to the content.

choices.B: a Custom navigation provider with security trimming

questions.question_text:
Your company is moving an on-premises Microsoft SharePoint Online.
The on-premises SharePoint deployment uses structural navigation with security trimming. After testing the same navigation approach in SharePoint Online, the company identifies the following requirements for the SharePoint Online deployment:
✑ Display an access denied page when users lack permissions to see a given page.
✑ Populate the navigation links based on a predefined company taxonomy.
✑ Display the same set of links to all users.
Which navigation approach should you recommend?

comments.content:
* Open the App catalog site, select the Apps for SharePoint list and then select new item
* Select the app and then select Open
* Select the Enabled check box in the app settings

discussion.content:
Choices are:
* Run the New File catalog cmdlet
* Select the app and then select Open
* Select the Featured check box in the App settings
* Open the App catalog site, select the Apps for SharePoint list and then select new item
* Run the Install-SPApp cmdlet
* Select the Enabled check box in the app settings

steps:
you go to app catalog site collection
then edit the properties of the app
then select Enabled checkbox 
finally Save

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You configure an App Catalog. You add several apps to the App Catalog.
Users report that when they attempt to add apps to sites, the new apps fail to appear.
You need to ensure that the users can add the apps to the sites.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of action to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
